awd_titl_txt: Applications of the Trace Formula to Shimura Varieties and the Langlands Program
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project concerns work in number theory, a branch of mathematics with applications to cryptography, coding theory, and cyber security. The Langlands program is a vast web of conjectures involving disparate areas of mathematics, with number theory playing a key central role. Fermat's Last Theorem followed from the verification of a small part of the Langlands program, and there are many other similar successes, often built upon fruitful interactions between objects encoding rich symmetries in different worlds: they are Shimura varieties (algebraic and complex geometry), automorphic forms (functional and harmonic analysis), and Galois theory. 

To deepen our understanding of these topics and especially the Langlands program, the principal investigator proposes to make new progress on the following problems: (1) new instances of the global Langlands correspondence for GSp(2n) and GSO(2n) (2) discrete Hecke orbit conjecture for Shimura varieties (3) local harmonic analysis questions for families of automorphic forms and (4) the p-adic Langlands program beyond GL(2,Qp). The output of research would stimulate further progress on these important problems and open up new research directions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The PI obtained noteworthy results in number theory in this project. In his joint work with Kisin and Zhu, the PI proved a version of the Langlands-Rapoport conjecture for Shimura varieties of abelian type, opening doors for further arithmetic applications in the Langlands program. Indeed, this result is pivotal for Kret and the PI in their work to obtain new instances of the global Langlands correspondence for general orthogonal groups, generalizing their earlier work for general symplectic groups. As another application of the work on the Langlands-Rapoport conjecture, Kret and the PI proved the discrete Hecke orbit conjecture and irreducibility of non-basic Igusa varieties for Hodge-type Shimura varieties. This is a significant improvement of earlier results. In a different direction, Fintzen and the PI applied type theory to generate many p-adic congruences between automorphic forms for general reductive groups, relating those with supercuspidal components at p and those with arbitrary components at p. 

The PI's research projects suggested problems and motivation for his PhD students, postdoc, and other members of the number theory group. To train the workforce, the PI co-organized at least a few seminars every semester in the Berkeley math department, partly in collaboration with Caltech and Stanford. The PI has been actively disseminating the outcomes of the projects by delivering lectures on numerous occasions, often targeted at mathematicians outside the field. Moreover, the PI has been writing expository papers on his research work and related background.

The PI's projects stemmed from basic questions in number theory that ancient Greeks had been trying to answer. Examples include studying properties of prime numbers and finding systematic solutions to polynomial equations in integers or rational numbers. Such developments in number theory are essential for human advances. As our society heavily relies on applications of number theory such as cryptography, errorcorrecting codes, and internetsecurity, our collective knowledge would shape future applications of number theory.
